subject: Management
title: Separating Impact From Intent
description: A micro-lesson that makes Separating Impact From Intent usable.

hook.text: He said it was just a joke. She said it was humiliating. Both were telling the truth.

buildup.text: Intent is what you meant. Impact is what the other person felt. They often don't match.

discovery.text: In conflict, people argue about intent. The actual damage comes from impact.

twist.text: Good intentions don't erase bad impact. And assuming bad intent escalates everything.

climax.text: Address impact first: I felt X when Y happened. Then explore intent together.

punchline.text: Impact is what happened. Intent is what you hoped. Start with what happened.

quiz.question: Why should you focus on impact rather than intent during conflict?
options: Impact is what actually caused harm regardless of what was meant
Intent is always more important than how people feel
Impact and intent are always the same in workplace settings
